ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes, wholeheartedly. It was a thorough approach to early modern historical drama from multiple critical and historical perspectives.
This is an excellent class for anyone interested in Shakespeare's history plays and in questions of English Renaissance historiography.

The course is a very interesting and detailed look at English history plays, primarily from the 1590s. Each week the students are expected to read one or two plays, usually one by Shakespeare and one by a contemporary dealing with the same subject. There is a lot of work to do, but also a lot of insights to gain from this approach, especially through the fruitful class discussions and Professor Manely's excellent comments, which are both textual and historical. The course should be of great interest to both English, Comp Lit, and History students.

I would definitely recommend it - it's an excellent way of approaching history plays by Shakespeare his contemporaries, and also provides interesting insights into the entire period of English history.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: It opened my eyes to a range of material which I had not previously considered very deeply, and to a period which I knew relatively little about (the late 1500s). Very insightful!
